  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath2 be a symmetric pair where @xmath3 is a semi - simple lie group with finite center .",
    "for @xmath3 compact let @xmath4 be the algebra under convolution generated by the invariant measures concentrated on conjugacy classes in @xmath3 , and @xmath5 be the convolution algebra generated by the invariant measures on spherical classes @xmath6 .",
    "it is elementary that @xmath7 and @xmath8 are commutative algebras with unit .",
    "these algebras arise naturally in random matrix theory , and theoretical physics .",
    "in fact , the product structures for generators of these algebras are given by the density functions of products of random matrices chosen according to invariant measures on conjugacy or spherical classes ; and in string theory generic d - branes are localized along the product of ( twisted ) conjugacy classes of the lie group",
    ". we will not discuss specific physical interpretations in this paper ( except for a remark in  5 ) , and the reader is referred to [ q ] , and references thereof , for a detailed discussion of the issues of interest in string theory .",
    "this work may be regarded as the initial attempt at understanding the structure of the hecke algebras @xmath9 and @xmath8 and considers only the special case of @xmath0 matrices .",
    "the support of the density function for products of two generators of @xmath10 is determined in [ aw ] and is exhibited by a set of linear inequalities on the lie algebra of a maximal torus .",
    "the result in [ aw ] is essentially a reformulation of a theorem about singular connections on a holomorphic vector bundle on a riemann surface with marked points [ b ] , or equivalently a theorem of mehta and seshadri in algebraic geometry .",
    "neither theorem is applicable for the computation of the density function for the product of two generators of the hecke algebra .",
    "a complete structure theorem for @xmath11 is given in theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] below .",
    "for spherical classes attached to groups of @xmath1 matrices we consider the symmetric pairs @xmath12 , @xmath13 and @xmath14 . theorem [ thm : shaffaf2 ] gives density functions for products of spherical classes . in the final section we present some numerical results in relation to products of conjugacy classes in @xmath15 .",
    "each conjugacy class , with the induced metric , is a copy of @xmath16 equipped with a metric of constant curvature .",
    "it is noticed ( perhaps surprisingly ) that if @xmath16 is dicretized according to the prescription of thomson s problem ( minimizing coulomb potential or intuitively `` the best equally spaced distribution '' ) then convergence to the predicted measure is much slower than if the points were chosen randomly .    in [ jm ]",
    "the question of whether a product of conjugacy classes @xmath17 contains the identity element and/or is the entire group @xmath15 is studied . by successive applications of theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] of this paper one",
    "can recover the results in [ jm ] and in fact give a more precise version of it .",
    "this subject has not been elaborated on here . the argument in [ jm ] depends on the results in [ aw ] , but the proofs presented here are self - contained and of a more elementary nature .",
    "the author wishes to thank a. katanforoush for the numerical results , r. szabo , m. sheikh - jabbari , s. shahshahani and especially mehrdad shahshahani for many stimulating discussions .",
    "a conjugacy class @xmath18 is uniquely determined by the eigenvalues @xmath19 of a matrix in @xmath20 .",
    "each conjugacy class is a homogeneous space , and for @xmath20 this measure @xmath21 is uniquely normalized to be @xmath22 in accordance with weyl s integration formula and the normalization @xmath23 .",
    "[ thm : shaffaf1 ] let @xmath24 and @xmath25 be the invariant measure on the conjugacy classes @xmath26 and @xmath27 respectively ( regarded as singular distribution on @xmath3 ) . then @xmath28 is an absolutely continuous conjugation invariant measure on @xmath3 relative to the haar measure and its density is given by @xmath29 where @xmath30 .",
    "let @xmath31 , then @xmath2 is a symmetric pair of compact type [ h1 ] .",
    "orbits of the action of @xmath32 on @xmath3 via @xmath33 are called spherical classes and are denoted by @xmath34 .",
    "@xmath35 is a homogeneous space and it is a simple calculation that @xmath36 is constant on @xmath34 and uniquely determines it . here @xmath37 is any matrix in @xmath34 .",
    "each spherical class @xmath35 carries an invariant measure @xmath38 .",
    "the total mass of the measure @xmath38 of a spherical class @xmath34 is @xmath39 , and we set @xmath40 .    in the non - compact cases",
    "@xmath41 and @xmath14 the real cartan subgroup @xmath42 is @xmath43 @xmath44 parametrizes spherical classes .",
    "the haar measure for the cartan ( polar ) decomposition @xmath45 is @xmath46 where @xmath47 is a suitable constant ( see [ h2 ] ) , @xmath48 , and @xmath49 according as @xmath50 or @xmath51 .",
    "the volume ( area ) of the spherical class @xmath52 is @xmath53^\\epsilon.\\ ] ]    [ thm : shaffaf2 ] the product formula for spherical classes in the three cases of symmetric pairs attached to groups of @xmath0 matrices are :    ( a)- let @xmath38 and @xmath54 be two ( singular ) spherical measures concentrated on the spherical classes @xmath34 and @xmath55 respectively . then @xmath56 is absolutely continuous relative to the haar measure on @xmath15 and given by @xmath57 where @xmath58 and @xmath59 are symmetric functions of @xmath60 and @xmath61 and given by @xmath62    \\(b ) - let @xmath63 and @xmath64 be the ( singular ) invariant measures concentrated on the spherical classes @xmath65 and @xmath66 in @xmath67",
    ". then @xmath68 is spherical and absolutely continuous relative to the haar measure , and for a continuous spherical function @xmath69 on @xmath70 we have @xmath71 where @xmath72 $ ] , @xmath73 , and @xmath74 .",
    "\\(c ) - let @xmath63 and @xmath64 be the ( singular ) invariant measures concentrated on the spherical classes @xmath65 and @xmath66 in @xmath51",
    ". then @xmath68 is spherical and absolutely continuous relative to the haar measure , and for a continuous spherical function @xmath69 on @xmath75 we have @xmath76 where @xmath72 $ ] .",
    "it may be of interest to normalize the measures on the spherical classes to probability measures and determine the corresponding empirical measure of products .",
    "for such a normalization the density functions determined in theorem [ thm : shaffaf2 ] become @xmath77    [ rem : shaffaf1]let @xmath78 and @xmath79 denote the completions of @xmath7 and @xmath8 in the weak topology . then in all cases considered",
    "@xmath78 and @xmath80 contain the corresponding @xmath81 space as a dense ideal .",
    "furthermore , by the above analysis , for every pair of generators @xmath82 and @xmath83 , we have @xmath84 .",
    "first we show that @xmath28 is an @xmath85 function for @xmath86 .",
    "the fourier expansion of the singular measure @xmath24 is given by    @xmath87,\\ ] ]    where @xmath88 is the set of irreducible representations of @xmath3 and the fourier transform of a measure @xmath89 is defined as @xmath90 this series does not converge in the ordinary sense of convergence of series of functions since the measure @xmath24 is singular , however , it converges in the weak sense .",
    "the convolution product @xmath28 can be calculated from @xmath91.\\ ] ] since the character @xmath92 is independent of @xmath93 , and is given by @xmath94 for @xmath95 is the symmetric @xmath96 representation of @xmath97 , @xmath98 applying the plancherel theorem to @xmath99 , we obtain @xmath100 this series converges absolutely and therefore @xmath28 is a square integrable function . from the cauchy - schwartz inequality",
    "it follows that @xmath28 is absolutely integrable .",
    "therefore the measure @xmath28 is a conjugation invariant function and it can be interpreted as the ( defective ) density function for the space of solutions @xmath47 to the equation @xmath101 since this density is conjugation invariant we represent it as the function @xmath102 on the maximal torus of diagonal matrices given by @xmath103 let @xmath104 denote the left regular representation of @xmath3 , and @xmath105 be the factor appearing in weyl integration formula for conjugacy invariant functions .",
    "the fourier transform of a function @xmath106 on @xmath3 at a representation @xmath95 is defined as @xmath107 let @xmath108 denote the dimension of the representation @xmath95 , @xmath109 its character and @xmath88 the space of ( complex ) irreducible representations of @xmath3 . taking fourier transform and decomposing the regular representation @xmath104 of @xmath3 in the usual way we obtain @xmath110 therefore @xmath111    irreducible representations of @xmath97 are determined by dimension @xmath112 .",
    "the character of the @xmath113-dimensional representation @xmath114 is : @xmath115 where @xmath19 is the eigenvalue of the conjugacy class of @xmath116 .",
    "substituting in ( [ eq : shaffaf6 ] ) we obtain @xmath117 now let @xmath118 denote the function defined by ( [ eq : shaffaf1 ] ) .",
    "since @xmath69 is an even function its fourier expansion is of the form @xmath119 , and @xmath120\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] substituting in the fourier expansion we obtain @xmath121 using the elementary identity @xmath122 the series becomes telescopic and simplifies to @xmath123 which is identical with ( [ eq : shaffaf7 ] ) .",
    "@xmath124    [ rem : shaffaf1 ] in the above proof we made use of the fact that the measure @xmath28 is a conjugation invariant function that can be interpreted as the ( defective ) density function for the space of solutions @xmath47 to the equation @xmath125 and this density is given by ( [ eq : shaffaf6 ] ) . for the case of finite groups",
    "this formula is well - known ( [ s ] , p.68 ) .",
    "[ rem : shaffaf2 ] it is possible to prove theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] without the use of harmonic analysis and by integral formulae similar to those used for the proof of theorem [ thm : shaffaf2 ] below",
    ". however , it appears that the above argument is possibly generalizable to products of conjugacy classes in compact connected semi - simple lie groups , but the one based on integral formulae is not .",
    "since the proofs of ( b ) and ( c ) are essentially the same computation we prove ( a ) and ( c ) only .",

    "the discretization and quantization of conjugacy classes are essentially different issues , and the latter is based on the kirillov orbit method ( see [ k ] ) .",
    "it is of interest in theoretical physics and is also relevant to the subject matter of this paper .",
    "the dual of the lie algebra of @xmath15 is identified with the set of @xmath1 skew hermitian matrices of trace 0 : @xmath184 under conjugation action of @xmath3 the orbits are the spheres @xmath185 .",
    "it is customary in physics to assign the symmetric @xmath96 power representation @xmath186 of @xmath15 to the sphere @xmath187 of area @xmath188 . according to the clebsch - gordon formula",
    ", @xmath189 decomposes as @xmath190 on the other hand the minkowski sum of spheres of radii @xmath191 and @xmath192 in @xmath193 is precisely the spherical shell defined by @xmath194 .",
    "the perfect resemblance between sums of spheres and the decomposition of the tensor product is carried over to the multiplication of conjugacy classes .",
    "in fact , we set ( note slight change of notation ) @xmath195 let @xmath196 mod @xmath197 and @xmath198 mod @xmath197 . by theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] @xmath199 the representations corresponding to conjugacy classes contained in @xmath200 correspond to those integers @xmath201 $ ] which @xmath202 mod 2 .",
    "thus in the range @xmath203 $ ] about half the representation occurring in @xmath200 appear in the clebsch - gordon formula .",
    "this is what is meant by the quantization of the product of two conjugacy classes .    by the discretization of products of conjugacy classes @xmath204 and @xmath205 one means the choice of @xmath206 points on each and the determination of the corresponding empirical measure of products of these points .",
    "if these @xmath206 points are chosen randomly according to the invariant measures on the conjugacy classes then the empirical measure of the products converges weakly to the density function ( [ eq : shaffaf1 ] ) by theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] and is numerically demonstrated in figures 1 for a typical choice with @xmath207 points .",
    "each conjugacy class @xmath208 is naturally equivalent to a copy of @xmath16 .",
    "it is therefore reasonable to investigate the weak convergence of the empirical measure if the points on @xmath16 are chosen according to the requirements of thomson s problem of distributing points on the sphere ( see [ ks ] ) .",
    "this means that the points should be distributed so that the coulomb potential @xmath209 is minimized .",
    "a variation of this problem for @xmath210 was originally posed by j. j. thomson in connection with his investigations of the structure of the atom in 1904 .",
    "it remains unsolved except for a few small values of @xmath206 , and it has also attracted attention for applications to complexity theory [ sm ] .",
    "the lattice point method makes use of the natural embedding of the icosahedron in @xmath16 and distributes @xmath211 points on the sphere in such a way that the distribution exhibits a high degree of symmetry and the points appear to be  evenly \" spaced .",
    "it was conjectured in [ a ] that this distribution will provide the solution to thomson s problem for @xmath212 .",
    "the polar coordinates method was devised in [ ks ] to achieve the minimum required by thomson s problem and numerical tests disproved the conjecture in [ a ] by showing that the ( local ) minimum achieved by the polar coordinates method ( where there was symmetry breakdown ) was in fact smaller .",
    "it is therefore natural to test the convergence of the empirical measure of products if the discretization is done according the polar coordinates or the lattice point methods . in figures 1 and 2 the convergence of the empirical measure to the density predicted by theorem [ thm : shaffaf1 ] is exhibited for @xmath207 points .",
    "the angles @xmath213 and @xmath106 in the captions refer to the conjugacy classes @xmath214 and @xmath215 respectively . in figures 2",
    "the corresponding empirical measures are calculated for the lattice point method and it is noticed that even if the measure converges to the density given by ( [ eq : shaffaf1 ] ) , the convergence is significantly slower .",
    "similar conclusion is applicable to the polar coordinates method as shown in figures 3 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the determination of the density functions for products of random elements from specified classes of matrices is a basic problem in random matrix theory and is also of interest in theoretical physics . for connected simple lie groups of @xmath0 matrices and conjugacy and spherical classes </S>",
    "<S> a complete solution is given here . </S>",
    "<S> the problem / solution can be re - stated in terms of the structure of certain hecke algebras attached to groups of @xmath1 matrices .    * on products of random matrices and certain hecke algebras associated with groups of @xmath1 matrices *        ams subject classification 2000 : 20e45 , 22e46 , 43a90 , 53c35 . </S>",
    "<S> 20c08 . </S>"
  ]
}
